2016

                        Clinton, Sanders and O'Malley will have a national audience Saturday but they'll be narrowcasting to a much smaller group of voters.

            By 
Gabriel Debenedetti

11/12/15 06:02 PM EST

                Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton, Sen. Bernie Sanders and Martin O'Malley talk backstage before the start of the Iowa Democratic Party's Jefferson-Jackson Dinner. | AP Photo

                                            By 
                                                    Jeff Greenfield


                                            By 
                                                    Neera Tanden


                                            By 
                                                    Rich Lowry


                                            By 
                                                    Jeff Greenfield

Iowa, Iowa, Iowa.
That’s the not-particularly-subtle message pervading Democratic camps as the party’s three remaining presidential candidates prep for their second debate Saturday night in Des Moines, a recognition that the first-caucusing state will likely play an even more outsized role than usual in 2016. 
Story Continued Below
While the direction of the questions may be squarely in the hands of debate host CBS News and moderator John Dickerson — whose role will be to manage the widely-expected fireworks coming from Bernie Sanders and Martin O’Malley — each of the candidates has already started sharpening the message (and spin) that they think will specifically take them furthest with the state’s influential voters.
“The Nevada debate was more of a national debate,” explained Sanders’ lead strategist, Tad Devine, echoing the beliefs of other top Democrats. “I do expect [this one] to be a debate that has more focus on Iowa."
For Sanders, that means heading north to his Burlington headquarters for two days starting Wednesday night to sit down with aides, and to scour briefing papers that include a deep-dive rundown on Iowa issues outlined by his staff on the ground there. He’s agreed to participate in mock debate run-throughs — after being resistant to such standard pre-debate fare last time — and his staff expects that he'll prepare specific policy contrasts to unleash against front-runner Hillary Clinton before he flies out to Des Moines on Friday.
For O’Malley, it’s meant all-but-shouting into a loudspeaker that he’ll aggressively attack Clinton and Sanders over their past records, recognizing that his poll numbers soon need to reach the neighborhood of the 15 percent viability threshold needed to win delegates from the state's precincts under the caucus rules if he plans to be a factor in the race. Eager to amp up the pressure, O’Malley won’t be sitting for long Baltimore prep sessions in the days leading up to the debate: instead, he was in Austin on Thursday meeting with a family that would benefit from the Deferred Action for Parents of Americans program, using the opportunity to further contrast with Sanders and Clinton over immigration. It's a policy area his team has identified as a winner for the former Maryland governor — who they hope to position as the true Democratic heir to Obama and his Iowa backers.



            By 
Noah Weiland

The front-running Clinton is taking a break from the campaign and cash trail after a pair of New York City fundraising events on Wednesday while her staff tries to manage her newly-sky-high expectations following her strong October. She just has to protect her lead in Iowa when she takes the Drake University stage, said a handful of people in her orbit, pointing to her speech at the state party’s Jefferson-Jackson dinner this fall as a guide. That means articulating a specific, forward-looking policy slate — and not taking the bait while her opponents eagerly pick at her past record.
The three divergent approaches will underscore the seemingly hard-wired caucus dynamics: a clear and dominant favorite chased by two challengers focused on proving they should be taken seriously. Democrats associated with all campaigns acknowledge if Clinton were to win Iowa — a state where she finished in third place in 2008 — handily in February, Sanders’ uphill path to the nomination would become even steeper. So his brain trust is squarely focused on keeping the margin close there.
“We recognize that she’s got a real lead there. A lot of it can be attributed to her having long-standing ties with voters, and institutional ties in both states. But she also had three months on television in Iowa and New Hampshire,” Devine said, alluding to the Clinton advertisements that plastered the early-voting states’ airwaves starting this summer.
But, he added, “We’ve looked at them as being states that are symbiotic. What happens in Iowa can drastically effect what happens in New Hampshire, so it’s very important for Bernie to demonstrate in Iowa that he is a strong national candidate who can compete with Hillary."
Clinton’s Iowa lead is 17 points, according to the Huffington Post Pollster average, and she’s down by 8 points in New Hampshire. (O’Malley sits 46 and 40 points behind the leader in each state, respectively.)
However, the former secretary of state’s aides are not eager to talk about locking up Iowa anytime soon — if anything, they are aiming to lower public expectations for Clinton’s debate performance. Following her strong showing in the first debate, Clinton is faced with the challenge of peeling away from her rivals without looking like she’s punching down — and defending herself while the others increasingly attack her for being untrustworthy or overly political.
As such, she’s unlikely to proactively go after either of her rivals in a specific way, like she did at the last debate in criticizing Sanders’ record on gun control.
“You’re much better off counterpunching than punching in her situation,” explained Bob Shrum, who was a senior advisor to both John Kerry in 2004 and Al Gore in 2000.
“I wouldn’t launch negative attacks. I don’t think there’s any big reason to do it right now. Going into the first debate they were very worried about Sanders’ surge. And I don’t think he’s still surging."
Team Sanders’ calculation is different: the senator’s campaign is running a soft, biography-laden television ad in both Iowa and New Hampshire, and he’s been focused on showing his personable side on the trail.



            By 
Nick Gass

But he’s also likely to challenge Clinton on a series of policy points, aides said, so they want him to use his prep sessions to find a way to strike the balance between being relatable to voters, and politically aggressive at the same time.
If that works, Sanders’ team expects to leverage its online fundraising tools to take its debate success to the bank, like last time, when it raised $2.5 million in the 24 hours after the forum — nearly double O’Malley's entire third-quarter haul.
The former Maryland governor is, accordingly, in the most precarious situation, forcing him to flash the most fire.
Believing that the narrowed field will give the candidate more time in the spotlight, O'Malley's allies predict an onslaught of criticism toward both Sanders — over his status as an independent and his call for a primary challenge to Obama in 2012 — and Clinton — over issues where she has shifted, most notably on immigration.
O’Malley has gone out of his way to needle Clinton over the last few days, most recently comparing her policies to Donald Trump's in a tweet after she reminded New Hampshire voters that she “voted numerous times when I was a senator to spend money to build a barrier to try to prevent illegal immigrants from coming in.” 
By lurching away from its hands-off-Clinton policy — borne out of fear of raising his name recognition through negative attacks — O'Malley's projected that he's likely to take his new tone to the debate stage in Des Moines, after his rhetoric reached its sharpest point yet at a Sunday immigration reform forum in Nevada:
“We are not going to solve this problem with poll-tested triangulation and half-truths,” he said. “Nor will we solve this problem by falsely asserting that immigrants take our jobs or lower our wages."
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
description: Clinton, Sanders and O'Malley will have a national audience Saturday but they'll be narrowcasting to a much smaller group of voters.
title: Democratic debate stamped with Iowa imprint
